descriptions.body: I take great care in making sure that my responsive builds look fantastic and feel intuitive—no matter what platform they’re being viewed on.

I’ve built great relationships with the designers I’ve worked with in the past and I’m always happy to provide guidance and constructive criticism where necessary in order to deliver a stunning* final product.
*exact level of stunningness dependent on design.

introduction: The art of presenting beautiful content for the web is something that still excites me to this day.
name: CSS

descriptions.body: The HTML behind your website is just as important as what’s presented to the user. I write meaningful, descriptive markup, not only to benefit search engine optimisation but also to provide assistive technologies with vital information for their users.
I’ve been lucky enough to work on a wide range of projects across sectors including finance, fitness, food, film and fashion. That’s a lot of Fs.

I’ve also worked on a large number of table-based HTML email campaigns, both responsive and non-responsive and, with the aid of copious amounts of tea, crying and swearing, have always ensured that they are cross-client compatible with pixel precision (hello Outlook).

introduction:
“We build too many walls and not enough bridges websites.”

— Isaac Newton Ian Hatton
name: HTML

descriptions.body: I've worked in many teams on a range of different tech stacks, which has broadened my knowledge and introduced me to a number of technologies along the way. I'm primarily a React developer, but am equally happy using anything else in my toolkit.
I’ve also written a number of vanilla JavaScript modules which are in use across several of the projects I’ve completed.

introduction: I'm in my element whether I'm writing vanilla JavaScript or applying that foundational knowledge to libraries and frameworks such as React, Next.js, Angular and anything beyond.
name: JavaScript

descriptions.body: Working in digital agencies has exposed me to a myriad of real-world requirements for web applications, including usability, accessibility and performance.
I’ve an understanding of MVC architecture and bespoke CMSs, but I’ve also had experience with the likes of WordPress, Tumblr and Shopify.
Over the years, I’ve factored in browser support all the way down to IE6, so I’m well-versed to the joys of cross-browser testing, compatibility issues and workarounds.
I also rocked GeoCities back in the day, but we don’t talk about that, do we?

introduction: Development fundamentals, platforms and anything else that didn’t quite fit into the other categories.
name: Bits and bobs
